Jim Cakalic wrote:

>  > From: junit@yahoogroups.com <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com> 
> [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com>] On Behalf
> Of
>  > J. B. Rainsberger
>  > Sent: Friday, November 24, 2006 1:02 PM
>  > To: junit@yahoogroups.com <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com>
>  > Subject: Re: [junit] Essay: The Trouble With JUnit
>  >
>  > What if I told you that someone was working on a book that teaches
>  > object-oriented design /entirely/ through test-driven development?
> What
>  > if I told you that such a book would likely have a Java version? Might
>  > that help?
> 
> Umm ... Agile Java <http://www.bookpool.com/sm/0131482394 
> <http://www.bookpool.com/sm/0131482394>> by Jeff
> Langr?
> 
> <quote>
> Agile Java represents a successful approach to learning and mastering
> Java development ... Using TDD, you will learn how to craft Java code to
> produce solid object-oriented designs and highly maintainable, high
> quality systems.
> </quote>

I wondered how much overlap there would be between my book and his. I 
haven't read Jeff's from beginning to end. I think we probably have 
similar content in spots, but slightly different goals. Part of me wants 
to read it to make sure I'm not rewriting it; part of me wants to avoid 
it so that I don't subconsciously rewrite it. I don't know how to deal 
with it.

Jeff, maybe we should talk about my idea and you can tell me whether I'd 
be rewriting your book. I feel no need to do that.

In the worst case, I would write mine in another language, which I was 
probably going to have to do, anyway.
-- 
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.ca
Your guide to software craftsmanship
JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
2005 Gordon Pask Award for contribution Agile Software Practice
